trans-unit.source: Managing Services
trans-unit.target: Managing Services

trans-unit.source: Managing Services
trans-unit.target: Managing Services

trans-unit.source: There are eight core Service cmdlets, designed for a wide range of service tasks .
trans-unit.target: There are eight core Service cmdlets, designed for a wide range of service tasks .

trans-unit.source: We will look only at listing and changing running state for services, but you can get a list Service cmdlets by using **Get\-Help \*\-Service**, and you can find information about each Service cmdlet by using **Get\-Help<Cmdlet\-Name>**, such as **Get\-Help New\-Service**.
trans-unit.target: We will look only at listing and changing running state for services, but you can get a list Service cmdlets by using **Get\-Help \*\-Service**, and you can find information about each Service cmdlet by using **Get\-Help<Cmdlet\-Name>**, such as **Get\-Help New\-Service**.

trans-unit.source: Getting Services
trans-unit.target: Getting Services

trans-unit.source: You can get the services on a local or remote computer by using the **Get\-Service** cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: You can get the services on a local or remote computer by using the **Get\-Service** cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: As with **Get\-Process**, using the **Get\-Service** command without parameters returns all services.
trans-unit.target: As with **Get\-Process**, using the **Get\-Service** command without parameters returns all services.

trans-unit.source: You can filter by name, even using an asterisk as a wildcard:
trans-unit.target: You can filter by name, even using an asterisk as a wildcard:

trans-unit.source: Because it is not always obvious what the real name for the service is, you may find you need to find services by display name.
trans-unit.target: Because it is not always obvious what the real name for the service is, you may find you need to find services by display name.

trans-unit.source: You can do this by specific name, using wildcards, or using a list of display names:
trans-unit.target: You can do this by specific name, using wildcards, or using a list of display names:

trans-unit.source: You can use the ComputerName parameter of the Get\-Service cmdlet to get the services on remote computers.
trans-unit.target: You can use the ComputerName parameter of the Get\-Service cmdlet to get the services on remote computers.

trans-unit.source: The ComputerName parameter accepts multiple values and wildcard characters, so you can get the services on multiple computers with a single command.
trans-unit.target: The ComputerName parameter accepts multiple values and wildcard characters, so you can get the services on multiple computers with a single command.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following command gets the services on the Server01 remote computer.
trans-unit.target: For example, the following command gets the services on the Server01 remote computer.

trans-unit.source: Getting Required and Dependent Services
trans-unit.target: Getting Required and Dependent Services

trans-unit.source: The Get\-Service cmdlet has two parameters that are very useful in service administration.
trans-unit.target: The Get\-Service cmdlet has two parameters that are very useful in service administration.

trans-unit.source: The DependentServices parameter gets services that depend on the service.
trans-unit.target: The DependentServices parameter gets services that depend on the service.

trans-unit.source: The RequiredServices parameter gets services upon which this service depends.
trans-unit.target: The RequiredServices parameter gets services upon which this service depends.

trans-unit.source: These parameters just display the values of the DependentServices and ServicesDependedOn (alias\=RequiredServices) properties of the System.ServiceProcess.ServiceController object that Get\-Service returns, but they simplify commands and make getting this information much simpler.
trans-unit.target: These parameters just display the values of the DependentServices and ServicesDependedOn (alias\=RequiredServices) properties of the System.ServiceProcess.ServiceController object that Get\-Service returns, but they simplify commands and make getting this information much simpler.

trans-unit.source: The following command gets the services that the LanmanWorkstation service requires.
trans-unit.target: The following command gets the services that the LanmanWorkstation service requires.

trans-unit.source: The following command gets the services that require the LanmanWorkstation service.
trans-unit.target: The following command gets the services that require the LanmanWorkstation service.

trans-unit.source: You can even get all services that have dependencies.
trans-unit.target: You can even get all services that have dependencies.

trans-unit.source: The following command does just that, and then it uses the Format\-Table cmdlet to display the Status, Name, RequiredServices and DependentServices properties of the services on the computer.
trans-unit.target: The following command does just that, and then it uses the Format\-Table cmdlet to display the Status, Name, RequiredServices and DependentServices properties of the services on the computer.

trans-unit.source: Stopping, Starting, Suspending, and Restarting Services
trans-unit.target: Stopping, Starting, Suspending, and Restarting Services

trans-unit.source: The Service cmdlets all have the same general form.
trans-unit.target: The Service cmdlets all have the same general form.

trans-unit.source: Services can be specified by common name or display name, and take lists and wildcards as values.
trans-unit.target: Services can be specified by common name or display name, and take lists and wildcards as values.

trans-unit.target: To stop the print spooler, use:

trans-unit.target: To start the print spooler after it is stopped, use:

trans-unit.source: To suspend the print spooler, use:
trans-unit.target: To suspend the print spooler, use:

trans-unit.source: The **Restart\-Service** cmdlet works in the same manner as the other Service cmdlets, but we will show some more complex examples for it.
trans-unit.target: The **Restart\-Service** cmdlet works in the same manner as the other Service cmdlets, but we will show some more complex examples for it.

trans-unit.source: In the simplest use, you specify the name of the service:
trans-unit.target: In the simplest use, you specify the name of the service:

trans-unit.source: You will notice that you get a repeated warning message about the Print Spooler starting up.
trans-unit.target: You will notice that you get a repeated warning message about the Print Spooler starting up.

trans-unit.source: When you perform a service operation that takes some time, Windows PowerShell will notify you that it is still attempting to perform the task.
trans-unit.target: When you perform a service operation that takes some time, Windows PowerShell will notify you that it is still attempting to perform the task.

trans-unit.source: If you want to restart multiple services, you can get a list of services, filter them, and then perform the restart:
trans-unit.target: If you want to restart multiple services, you can get a list of services, filter them, and then perform the restart:

trans-unit.source: These Service cmdlets do not have a ComputerName parameter, but you can run them on a remote computer by using the Invoke\-Command cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: These Service cmdlets do not have a ComputerName parameter, but you can run them on a remote computer by using the Invoke\-Command cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following command restarts the Spooler service on the Server01 remote computer.
trans-unit.target: For example, the following command restarts the Spooler service on the Server01 remote computer.

trans-unit.source: Setting Service Properties
trans-unit.target: Setting Service Properties

trans-unit.source: The Set\-Service cmdlet changes the properties of a service on a local or remote computer.
trans-unit.target: The Set\-Service cmdlet changes the properties of a service on a local or remote computer.

trans-unit.source: Because the service status is a property, you can use this cmdlet to start, stop, and suspend a service.
trans-unit.target: Because the service status is a property, you can use this cmdlet to start, stop, and suspend a service.

trans-unit.source: The Set\-Service cmdlet also has a StartupType parameter that lets you change the service startup type.
trans-unit.target: The Set\-Service cmdlet also has a StartupType parameter that lets you change the service startup type.

trans-unit.source: To use Set\-Service on Windows Vista and later versions of Windows, open Windows PowerShell with the "Run as administrator" option.
trans-unit.target: To use Set\-Service on Windows Vista and later versions of Windows, open Windows PowerShell with the "Run as administrator" option.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Set-Service [m2]](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/b71e29ed-372b-4e32-a4b7-5eb6216e56c3)
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Set-Service [m2]](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/b71e29ed-372b-4e32-a4b7-5eb6216e56c3)
